text.p: Again, let [mathjaxinline]T: \mathbb R^ n \rightarrow \mathbb R^ m[/mathjaxinline] be a linear transformation. Given the above, if [mathjaxinline]n<m[/mathjaxinline], is it possible for [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] to be invertible?
If [mathjaxinline]n>m[/mathjaxinline], is it possible for [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] to be invertible?

font.p: We know that, if [mathjaxinline]n<m[/mathjaxinline] or if [mathjaxinline]n>m[/mathjaxinline], [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] can't be both into and onto. Therefore, in neither case could [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] be invertible.
